taxonomy.Species: Arm Triangle From Knee on Belly

labels.Aliases: KOB Kata Gatame (Arm-Isolation) | Knee Ride Head-and-Arm | Knee-on-Belly Arm Triangle
labels.Description: A head-and-arm choke (kata gatame) applied from knee-on-belly. The attacker pins the opponent with the knee ride, isolates the near arm across the opponent’s neck, and drives the shoulder and chest into the carotid while locking a head-and-arm clamp. Finish is created by shoulder adduction, chest pressure, and angle change—not by leg triangling.
labels.Biomechanical Mechanism: Action | Lateral vascular compression using opponent’s trapped arm against their neck plus attacker’s shoulder/chest pressure || Joints Affected | Neck (carotid arteries), shoulder of the trapped arm || Torque/Force | Shoulder adduction with scapular protraction; chest drop; head positioning to close space; base stabilized by knee-on-belly
labels.Position / Entry Examples: From side control, post to **knee-on-belly** (knee centered, toes active). With your **right hand** cross-face across the jawline to turn the head away; your left hand controls the near wrist/triceps and **feeds the arm across** the opponent’s neck. Slide your **right arm under the head** and around the opponent’s neck/arm, connect palms (gable) or RNC-style (grab right biceps, left hand to crown). Keep knee pressure to pin hips, **drop right shoulder** toward the neck, **walk your body toward the head at ~45°**, and sprawl the left leg for base. Squeeze elbows, drive chest, and micro-adjust head position to close the space for the choke. Optionally transition to mount while maintaining the lock if you need more pressure.
labels.Danger Rating: Danger: 9/10 | Direct vascular choke from dominant top control; loss of consciousness can be fast once sealed.
labels.Legality in Competition: IBJJF: Legal | Judo: Legal | MMA: Legal | Submission Grappling: Legal
labels.Variants: High-knee pin to kata gatame || Knee-on-belly to mounted kata gatame finish || Wrist-control (C-grip) feed across || Underhook drag feed across
labels.Training Notes: Maintain knee ride pressure to stop hip shrimping || Keep the opponent’s elbow **high and across**—if it slips below the chin, reset the feed || Finish by **angling** (walk toward the head and drop shoulder), not just squeezing arms || If space remains, transition to mount or switch to d’arce/anaconda as the arm slips.
labels.History / Origin: Modern BJJ adaptation of kata gatame that emphasizes using the mobile knee-on-belly pin to create the arm-across feed and immediate finishing pressure.
labels.Common Mistakes: Trying to finish without the arm truly across the neck || Leaning too far forward and getting rolled || Keeping head too high (leaves space) || Squeezing without walking angle/shoulder drop (becomes neck crank instead of choke).
labels.Effectiveness: Effective as both a submission and a control threat. The knee-on-belly base limits opponent’s mobility while the head-and-arm isolation creates constant choke pressure. While not always as tight as mounted kata gatame, it reliably forces defensive reactions that open transitions (to mount, back takes, or d’arce/anaconda). Finishing potential is high if proper shoulder drop and angle are achieved.
labels.Related Techniques: Side control arm triangle (kata gatame) || Mount arm triangle || D’arce choke || Anaconda choke
labels.Tags: knee on belly arm triangle | kob kata gatame | head-and-arm choke | BJJ | Judo | MMA | top control submission
labels.Notes: Functions as both a submission and control position—if choke fails, attacker can transition smoothly into mount, armbar, or back take.
